Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Summer Undergraduate Research Program in Biochemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to Texas A&M AgriLife Research and the Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics at Texas A&M University, located in College Station, TX, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2014-2018. This project is supported by both the Directorates for Biological Sciences (Division of Biological Infrastructure) and Mathematical and Physical Sciences (Division of Chemistry). The Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics at Texas A&M offers an energetic atmosphere to perform research in diverse areas of biochemistry, including, but not limited to, genomics, proteomics, enzymology, structural biology, mechanisms of gene expression, membrane structure and function, and developmental/cell biology. Recruiting efforts will focus on students who have completed their junior or sophomore year and who attend institutions that do not offer doctoral degrees. Although not limited to this geographical area, special recruiting efforts will be made to attract students from universities and colleges in Texas and surrounding states in the mid-South region. Partner institutions that enroll substantial numbers of students who are underrepresented in STEM fields will help recruit students to this program. Participants will evaluate the program at the end of their summer experience and in subsequent years, using the online BIO REU common assessment tool and a program-specific questionnaire.

Significant broader impacts will result from the summer research program. Participants will receive training from faculty advisors who direct nationally funded research programs. Weekly meetings will provide training in responsible conduct in research, critical analysis of research literature, development of hypothesis-driven research and instruction in presentation skills. At the conclusion of the program students will present their research accomplishments in both written and oral reports. Participants will leave with an appreciation of the effort and satisfaction involved in biochemical research, and prepared to pursue graduate training and careers in this area. A majority of previous participants have enrolled in graduate school or obtained research positions in academia or industry.

Students are required to be tracked after participating in this program and must respond to an automatic email sent by the NSF reporting system. More information is available at http://biochemistry.tamu.edu/academics/reu/summer-undergraduate-research-in-biochemistry/, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Gary R. Kunkel at g-kunkel@tamu.edu) or co-PI (Dr. Mary Bryk at bryk@tamu.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
We administered a NSF-REU program in biochemistry in the Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics at Texas A&M University during the summers of 2014 through 2019. This Summer Undergraduate Research Program in Biochemistry lasted almost 10 weeks and coincided with the summer session at the university. Six - 10 students who had completed their junior or sophomore year in college were recruited annually from universities and colleges throughout the U.S., particularly from institutions that do not offer doctoral degrees. Special recruiting efforts were made to attract students from universities and colleges in Texas and surrounding states in the mid-South region. Within this region several partner institutions that enroll substantial numbers of underrepresented minority students were asked to identify students to submit applications to the program. During the period of this grant, 1154 students submitted applications and 56 students were supported by NSF funds. 33 additional students participated with funding provided by other sources, primarily from Texas A&M University. The pool of NSF-supported participants was diverse, with 68% female, and 52% from ethnic groups underrepresented in science and engineering.

 

The intellectual merit of this program is based on the participation of undergraduate students in cutting-edge research in biochemistry. The Department of Biochemistry and Biophysics at Texas A&M University offers an energetic atmosphere to perform research in diverse areas of biochemistry, including, but not limited to, bioinformatics, genomics and proteomics, enzymology, structural biology, mechanisms of gene expression, membrane structure and function, and developmental/cell biology. Undergraduate participants received training from faculty advisors who direct nationally-funded research programs. Weekly meetings provided training in research ethics, critical analysis of research literature, development of hypothesis-driven research and instruction in presentation skills. At the conclusion of the program the students presented their research accomplishments in both written and oral reports.

 

Very significant broader impacts resulted from the summer research program. REU students departed with an appreciation of the effort and satisfaction involved in biochemical research, and were prepared to pursue graduate training and careers in this area. Many participants enrolled subsequently in graduate school or obtained research assistant positions in academia or industry. At one year after participation in our program at least 48% had enrolled in graduate programs in science or were employed in research positions. We note that 26% were still undergraduate students, and a high percentage of these students were likely to enroll later in graduate degree programs. Participant ratings of our program were high. Using a 5-point scale with 5 being the highest, participants reported with annual ratings between 4.56 and 4.80 that ?this program helped me to increase my research skills.? Likewise, annual ratings between 4.69 and 4.87 responded to the query of ?I would recommend this program to others.?

 

In the future, our summer research program will be supported by another NSF-REU renewal grant, and we look forward to continuing the training of a diverse group of undergraduate students for future careers in science.
